sentences.sentence: While much has been made of the recent federal budget, which includes new and expanded spending on stimulus, national daycare, new green initiatives and much, much more, there has been relatively little discussion about its increased payments to seniors.

But they are one of the most ill-considered policies announced in the budget.The budget outlines plans to spend $12 billion (which used to be serious money in Canada) over the next five years to finance both a 10 per cent increase in the Old Age Security (OAS) benefit starting in 2022 as well as a one-time $500 payment to OAS recipients 75 and older.
The government estimates the continuing benefit will provide 3.3 million seniors extra income of roughly $766 annually.

Purely coincidentally, no doubt, the one-time payment is scheduled for this fall, when many observers expect an election to be called.According to the budget, this spending increase is necessary because "many seniors have faced economic challenges as they took on extra costs to stay safe" during COVID and "many seniors are living longer and relying on monthly benefits to afford retirement."

The first statement seems to contradict other parts of the budget, which assure Canadians that we're emerging from the pandemic and starting to return to normal.The basics of OAS are important to understand as they explain why the increase is bad policy.
OAS is a flat benefit paid to eligible seniors 65 years of age and older.
Eligible seniors with incomes up to $79,845 (2021) receive the full benefit, which is roughly $618 per month.
Seniors with higher incomes experience a 15 per cent clawback, which means those with incomes between $79,846 and $129,260 receive partial OAS benefits.

OAS benefits are determined individually, which means a couple can have an annual household income up to almost $160,000 and still receive full OAS benefits, or household income up to $258,520 and receive partial OAS benefits.The most obvious problem with the government's policy is that it doesn't target assistance to those in need.

This is a consistent problem with the Trudeau government, but it is especially glaring in this instance because there's already a program, the Guaranteed Income Supplement, which provides additional income support to low-income seniors.
If the government wanted to get assistance to those in need while at the same time controlling costs, it could simply increase GIS benefits.Opinion: Federal budget: Spend.

Then spend more than that(https://financialpost.com/opinion/opinion-federal-budget-spend-spend-more-then-spend-more-than-that)Matthew Lau: Ontario's 'Human Fund' budget(https://financialpost.com/opinion/matthew-lau-ontarios-human-fund-budget)Opinion: Guaranteed income would be a costly proposition(https://financialpost.com/opinion/opinion-guaranteed-income-would-be-a-costly-proposition)Opinion: Poor CERB targeting wastes billions(https://financialpost.com/opinion/opinion-poor-cerb-targeting-wastes-billions)A final concern is that the government is proposing this poorly targeted increase in the OAS, which on the surface looks like politics trumping good policy in advance of an election, during a time of historically unprecedented borrowing.

Ottawa borrowed $354.2 billion last year, and in a best-case scenario expects to borrow another $331.9 billion over the next five years, bringing the national debt (adjusted for financial assets) to at least $1.5 trillion.

If economic growth is slower than expected, however, and inflation and/or interest rates higher, required borrowing could be much greater than planned.The prudent policy for a government concerned with the incomes of seniors would have been to target assistance to those in need, thus limiting the costs, including increased public debt, of the expanded program.

Instead, the Trudeau government has again demonstrated it is not concerned about spending beyond its means or piling up debt.Jason Clemens, Milagros Palacios and Niels Veldhuis are analysts at the Fraser Institute.
